hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## COMBINED	NOTES	TO	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS

Under	each	of	the	NEIL	policies,	members	are	subject	to	assessments	each	year	if	losses	exceed	the	accumulated	funds available	to	the	insurer.	The	maximum	annual	assessments	for	Alabama	Power	and	Georgia	Power	as	of	December	31,	2023	under the	NEIL	policies	would	be	$54	million	and	$89	million,	respectively.

Claims	resulting	from	terrorist	acts	and	cyber	events	are	covered	under	both	the	ANI	and	NEIL	policies	(subject	to	normal policy	limits).	The	maximum	aggregate	that	NEIL	will	pay	for	all	claims	resulting	from	terrorist	acts	and	cyber	events	in	any 12-month	period	is	$3.2	billion	each,	plus	such	additional	amounts	NEIL	can	recover	through	reinsurance,	indemnity,	or	other sources.

For	all	on-site	property	damage	insurance	policies	for	commercial	nuclear	power	plants,	the	NRC	requires	that	the	proceeds	of such	policies	shall	be	dedicated	first	for	the	sole	purpose	of	placing	the	reactor	in	a	safe	and	stable	condition	after	an accident.	Any	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	applied	next	toward	the	costs	of	decontamination	and	debris	removal	operations ordered	by	the	NRC,	and	any	further	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	paid	either	to	the	applicable	company	or	to	its	debt trustees	as	may	be	appropriate	under	the	policies	and	applicable	trust	indentures.	In	the	event	of	a	loss,	the	amount	of insurance	available	might	not	be	adequate	to	cover	property	damage	and	other	expenses	incurred.	Uninsured	losses	and	other expenses,	to	the	extent	not	recovered	from	customers,	would	be	borne	by	Alabama	Power	or	Georgia	Power,	as	applicable,	and could	have	a	material	effect	on	Southern	Company's,	Alabama	Power's,	and	Georgia	Power's	financial	condition	and	results	of operations.

All	retrospective	assessments,	whether	generated	for	liability,	property,	or	replacement	power,	may	be	subject	to	applicable state	premium	taxes.

## Other	Matters

## Traditional	Electric	Operating	Companies

In	April	2019,	Bellsouth	Telecommunications	d/b/a	AT&T	Alabama	(AT&T)	filed	a	complaint	against	Alabama	Power	with	the	FCC alleging	that	the	pole	rental	rate	AT&T	is	required	to	pay	pursuant	to	the	parties'	joint	use	agreement	is	unjust	and unreasonable	under	federal	law.	The	complaint	sought	a	new	rate	and	approximately	$87	million	in	refunds	of	alleged overpayments	for	the	preceding	six	years.	In	August	2019,	the	FCC	stayed	the	case	in	favor	of	arbitration,	which	AT&T	has	not pursued.	The	joint	use	agreement	remains	in	effect.	The	ultimate	outcome	of	this	matter	cannot	be	determined	at	this	time, but	an	adverse	outcome	could	have	a	material	impact	on	the	financial	statements	of	Southern	Company	and	Alabama	Power. Georgia	Power	and	Mississippi	Power	have	joint	use	agreements	with	other	AT&T	affiliates.

## Mississippi	Power

## Kemper	County	Energy	Facility

In	2021,	2022,	and	2023,	Mississippi	Power	recorded	charges	to	income	associated	with	abandonment	and	related	closure	costs and	ongoing	period	costs,	net	of	salvage	proceeds,	for	the	mine	and	gasifier-related	assets	at	the	Kemper	County	energy facility.	These	charges,	including	related	tax	impacts,	totaled	$11	million	pre-tax	($8	million	after	tax)	in	2021,	$15 million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2022,	and	$17	million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2023.	The	pre-tax	charges are	included	in	other	operations	and	maintenance	expenses	on	the	statements	of	income.

Dismantlement	of	the	abandoned	gasifier-related	assets	and	site	restoration	activities	are	expected	to	be	completed	by	2026. Additional	pre-tax	period	costs	associated	with	dismantlement	and	site	restoration	activities,	including	related	costs	for compliance	and	safety,	ARO	accretion,	and	property	taxes,	net	of	salvage,	are	estimated	to	total	approximately	$15	million annually	through	2025.

Mississippi	Power	owns	the	lignite	mine	located	around	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility	site.	As	a	result	of	the	abandonment of	the	Kemper	IGCC,	final	mine	reclamation	began	in	2018	and	was	substantially	completed	in	2020,	with	monitoring	expected	to continue	through	2028.

As	the	mining	permit	holder,	Liberty	Fuels	Company,	LLC,	a	wholly-owned	subsidiary	of	The	North	American	Coal	Corporation, has	a	legal	obligation	to	perform	mine	reclamation	and	Mississippi	Power	has	a	contractual	obligation	to	fund	all	reclamation activities.	See	Note	6	for	additional	information.

See	"General	Litigation	Matters	Southern	Company	and	Mississippi	Power"	herein	for	information	regarding	litigation associated	with	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility.

## Plant	Daniel

In	conjunction	with	Southern	Company's	2019	sale	of	Gulf	Power,	NextEra	Energy	held	back	$75	million	of	the	purchase	price pending	Mississippi	Power	and	NextEra	Energy	negotiating	a	mutually	acceptable	revised	operating	agreement	for	Plant	Daniel. In	July	2022,	the	co-owners	executed	a	revised	operating	agreement	and	Southern	Company	subsequently	received	the	remaining $75	million	of	the	purchase	price.	The	dispatch	procedures	in	the	revised	operating	agreement	for	the	two	jointly-owned	coal units

questions.question: How do the potential insurance-related financial obligations of Georgia Power, as detailed in Southern Company's 10-K filing, relate to the broader risk exposure of Southern Company, and what is the total maximum annual assessment for both Georgia Power and Alabama Power combined?
questions.answer: Georgia Power, as a subsidiary of Southern Company, is subject to maximum annual insurance assessments under NEIL policies. As of December 31, 2023, Georgia Power's maximum annual assessment is $89 million, while Alabama Power's is $54 million. These assessments represent potential financial obligations that could impact Southern Company's consolidated financial position, especially in the event of a nuclear incident or other insured loss where insurance proceeds are insufficient to cover incurred costs. The combined maximum annual assessment for both Georgia Power and Alabama Power is $143 million.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power is a subsidiary of Southern Company, indicating a direct financial relationship and risk exposure.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power’s maximum annual assessment under NEIL policies is $89 million, and Alabama Power’s is $54 million.
Step 3: Synthesize - These assessments represent potential liabilities that could affect Southern Company's financial condition, especially if insurance proceeds are inadequate to cover losses.
Step 4: Calculate - The total maximum annual assessment for both companies combined is $89 million + $54 million = $143 million.

questions.question: What is the total potential financial exposure for Georgia Power in the event of a nuclear accident, considering both the maximum annual retrospective assessment under the NEIL policy and the potential inadequacy of insurance proceeds, and how does this exposure relate to the allocation of assets in Georgia Power's portfolio as of December 31, 2023?
questions.answer: Georgia Power's total potential financial exposure in the event of a nuclear accident includes a maximum annual retrospective assessment of $89 million under the NEIL policy. Additionally, if insurance proceeds are inadequate to cover property damage and other expenses, uninsured losses would be borne by Georgia Power, potentially impacting its financial condition. Given that Georgia Power's portfolio as of December 31, 2023, includes $409 million in total assets with a 57% allocation to equity (primarily domestic and international equities totaling $109 million) and 35% to fixed income (totaling $30 million), a significant uninsured loss could disproportionately affect its equity and fixed income positions, straining its financial stability.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power's maximum annual retrospective assessment under NEIL policy is $89 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - In the event of a loss, insurance may be inadequate, and uninsured losses would be borne by Georgia Power, potentially impacting its financial condition.

Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power's total assets as of December 31, 2023, amount to $409 million, with $109 million allocated to equity (domestic and international) and $30 million to fixed income.

Step 4: Synthesize - The $89 million NEIL assessment, combined with potential uninsured losses, could significantly impact Georgia Power's financial stability, especially given its asset allocation, which includes a large portion in equity and fixed income that may be used to cover such liabilities.

These	charges,	including	related	tax	impacts,	totaled	$11	million	pre-tax	($8	million	after	tax)	in	2021,	$15 million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2022,	and	$17	million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2023.	The	pre-tax	charges are	included	in	other	operations	and	maintenance	expenses	on	the	statements	of	income.

Dismantlement	of	the	abandoned	gasifier-related	assets	and	site	restoration	activities	are	expected	to	be	completed	by	2026. Additional	pre-tax	period	costs	associated	with	dismantlement	and	site	restoration	activities,	including	related	costs	for compliance	and	safety,	ARO	accretion,	and	property	taxes,	net	of	salvage,	are	estimated	to	total	approximately	$15	million annually	through	2025.

Mississippi	Power	owns	the	lignite	mine	located	around	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility	site.	As	a	result	of	the	abandonment of	the	Kemper	IGCC,	final	mine	reclamation	began	in	2018	and	was	substantially	completed	in	2020,	with	monitoring	expected	to continue	through	2028.

As	the	mining	permit	holder,	Liberty	Fuels	Company,	LLC,	a	wholly-owned	subsidiary	of	The	North	American	Coal	Corporation, has	a	legal	obligation	to	perform	mine	reclamation	and	Mississippi	Power	has	a	contractual	obligation	to	fund	all	reclamation activities.	See	Note	6	for	additional	information.

See	"General	Litigation	Matters	Southern	Company	and	Mississippi	Power"	herein	for	information	regarding	litigation associated	with	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility.

## Plant	Daniel

In	conjunction	with	Southern	Company's	2019	sale	of	Gulf	Power,	NextEra	Energy	held	back	$75	million	of	the	purchase	price pending	Mississippi	Power	and	NextEra	Energy	negotiating	a	mutually	acceptable	revised	operating	agreement	for	Plant	Daniel. In	July	2022,	the	co-owners	executed	a	revised	operating	agreement	and	Southern	Company	subsequently	received	the	remaining $75	million	of	the	purchase	price.	The	dispatch	procedures	in	the	revised	operating	agreement	for	the	two	jointly-owned	coal units

questions.question: How do the potential insurance assessments and debt obligations tied to Georgia Power impact Southern Company's overall financial exposure as revealed across the 10-K filings?
questions.answer: Southern Company's overall financial exposure is significantly heightened due to its stake in Georgia Power, which faces a maximum annual insurance assessment of $89 million under NEIL policies. Additionally, Georgia Power has multiple debt obligations, including senior and subordinated notes, loan guarantees, and promissory notes, which collectively increase the financial risk to Southern Company. If Georgia Power incurs uninsured losses or is required to pay these assessments, Southern Company would bear the financial burden, potentially affecting its financial condition and results of operations.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power has multiple debt obligations, including senior notes, subordinated notes, loan guarantees, and promissory notes, indicating significant financial commitments.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power is subject to a maximum annual insurance assessment of $89 million under NEIL policies, which could result in substantial cash outflows.

Step 3: Synthesize - Southern Company, as the parent entity, is financially exposed to Georgia Power's obligations and insurance assessments. If Georgia Power incurs uninsured losses or must pay these assessments, Southern Company would bear the costs, increasing its overall financial risk.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## COMBINED	NOTES	TO	FINANCIAL	STATEMENTS

Under	each	of	the	NEIL	policies,	members	are	subject	to	assessments	each	year	if	losses	exceed	the	accumulated	funds available	to	the	insurer.	The	maximum	annual	assessments	for	Alabama	Power	and	Georgia	Power	as	of	December	31,	2023	under the	NEIL	policies	would	be	$54	million	and	$89	million,	respectively.

Claims	resulting	from	terrorist	acts	and	cyber	events	are	covered	under	both	the	ANI	and	NEIL	policies	(subject	to	normal policy	limits).	The	maximum	aggregate	that	NEIL	will	pay	for	all	claims	resulting	from	terrorist	acts	and	cyber	events	in	any 12-month	period	is	$3.2	billion	each,	plus	such	additional	amounts	NEIL	can	recover	through	reinsurance,	indemnity,	or	other sources.

For	all	on-site	property	damage	insurance	policies	for	commercial	nuclear	power	plants,	the	NRC	requires	that	the	proceeds	of such	policies	shall	be	dedicated	first	for	the	sole	purpose	of	placing	the	reactor	in	a	safe	and	stable	condition	after	an accident.	Any	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	applied	next	toward	the	costs	of	decontamination	and	debris	removal	operations ordered	by	the	NRC,	and	any	further	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	paid	either	to	the	applicable	company	or	to	its	debt trustees	as	may	be	appropriate	under	the	policies	and	applicable	trust	indentures.	In	the	event	of	a	loss,	the	amount	of insurance	available	might	not	be	adequate	to	cover	property	damage	and	other	expenses	incurred.	Uninsured	losses	and	other expenses,	to	the	extent	not	recovered	from	customers,	would	be	borne	by	Alabama	Power	or	Georgia	Power,	as	applicable,	and could	have	a	material	effect	on	Southern	Company's,	Alabama	Power's,	and	Georgia	Power's	financial	condition	and	results	of operations.

All	retrospective	assessments,	whether	generated	for	liability,	property,	or	replacement	power,	may	be	subject	to	applicable state	premium	taxes.

## Other	Matters

## Traditional	Electric	Operating	Companies

In	April	2019,	Bellsouth	Telecommunications	d/b/a	AT&T	Alabama	(AT&T)	filed	a	complaint	against	Alabama	Power	with	the	FCC alleging	that	the	pole	rental	rate	AT&T	is	required	to	pay	pursuant	to	the	parties'	joint	use	agreement	is	unjust	and unreasonable	under	federal	law.	The	complaint	sought	a	new	rate	and	approximately	$87	million	in	refunds	of	alleged overpayments	for	the	preceding	six	years.	In	August	2019,	the	FCC	stayed	the	case	in	favor	of	arbitration,	which	AT&T	has	not pursued.	The	joint	use	agreement	remains	in	effect.	The	ultimate	outcome	of	this	matter	cannot	be	determined	at	this	time, but	an	adverse	outcome	could	have	a	material	impact	on	the	financial	statements	of	Southern	Company	and	Alabama	Power. Georgia	Power	and	Mississippi	Power	have	joint	use	agreements	with	other	AT&T	affiliates.

## Mississippi	Power

questions.question: How much could Georgia Power be assessed annually under the NEIL policies, and how does this potential liability compare to Southern Company's total fair value loss from its hedging activities as reported in the financial statements?
questions.answer: Georgia Power could be assessed up to $89 million annually under the NEIL policies. Southern Company reported a total fair value loss of $264 million from its hedging activities as of December 31, 2023. Therefore, the potential annual assessment for Georgia Power represents approximately 33.7% of Southern Company's total fair value loss from hedging.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power's maximum annual assessment under NEIL policies is $89 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_a - Southern Company's total fair value loss from hedging activities is $264 million as of December 31, 2023.
Step 3: Calculate percentage - ($89 million ÷ $264 million) × 100 = 33.7%.

Step 4: Synthesize - The potential liability from NEIL assessments for Georgia Power represents a significant portion (33.7%) of Southern Company's total reported fair value loss from its hedging activities.

questions.question: How does Georgia Power's exposure to nuclear insurance assessments and long-term energy procurement commitments jointly affect Southern Company's financial risk profile?
questions.answer: Georgia Power's maximum annual assessment under NEIL nuclear insurance policies is $89 million, which could be triggered if losses exceed accumulated funds. Additionally, Georgia Power has long-term energy procurement commitments extending to 2026, as shown by its 128 mmBtu net purchased volume and longest hedge date in 2026. These commitments expose Georgia Power to both potential insurance liabilities and ongoing energy cost risks. Since Georgia Power is a subsidiary of Southern Company, these exposures directly influence Southern Company's consolidated financial risk, particularly in terms of unexpected liabilities and long-term cost structures. This dual exposure could materially affect Southern Company's financial condition and results of operations.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power has a longest hedge date of 2026 and a net purchased volume of 128 mmBtu, indicating long-term energy procurement commitments.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power has a maximum annual assessment of $89 million under NEIL nuclear insurance policies, representing potential liabilities.

Step 3: Synthesize - These two financial exposures (insurance assessments and long-term energy contracts) combine to create a multi-dimensional risk profile for Georgia Power, which flows up to Southern Company.
Step 4: Conclude - The question requires understanding both risk categories and their joint impact on Southern Company's financial stability, making it multi-hop and causal.

For	all	on-site	property	damage	insurance	policies	for	commercial	nuclear	power	plants,	the	NRC	requires	that	the	proceeds	of such	policies	shall	be	dedicated	first	for	the	sole	purpose	of	placing	the	reactor	in	a	safe	and	stable	condition	after	an accident.	Any	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	applied	next	toward	the	costs	of	decontamination	and	debris	removal	operations ordered	by	the	NRC,	and	any	further	remaining	proceeds	are	to	be	paid	either	to	the	applicable	company	or	to	its	debt trustees	as	may	be	appropriate	under	the	policies	and	applicable	trust	indentures.	In	the	event	of	a	loss,	the	amount	of insurance	available	might	not	be	adequate	to	cover	property	damage	and	other	expenses	incurred.	Uninsured	losses	and	other expenses,	to	the	extent	not	recovered	from	customers,	would	be	borne	by	Alabama	Power	or	Georgia	Power,	as	applicable,	and could	have	a	material	effect	on	Southern	Company's,	Alabama	Power's,	and	Georgia	Power's	financial	condition	and	results	of operations.

All	retrospective	assessments,	whether	generated	for	liability,	property,	or	replacement	power,	may	be	subject	to	applicable state	premium	taxes.

## Other	Matters

## Traditional	Electric	Operating	Companies

In	April	2019,	Bellsouth	Telecommunications	d/b/a	AT&T	Alabama	(AT&T)	filed	a	complaint	against	Alabama	Power	with	the	FCC alleging	that	the	pole	rental	rate	AT&T	is	required	to	pay	pursuant	to	the	parties'	joint	use	agreement	is	unjust	and unreasonable	under	federal	law.	The	complaint	sought	a	new	rate	and	approximately	$87	million	in	refunds	of	alleged overpayments	for	the	preceding	six	years.	In	August	2019,	the	FCC	stayed	the	case	in	favor	of	arbitration,	which	AT&T	has	not pursued.	The	joint	use	agreement	remains	in	effect.	The	ultimate	outcome	of	this	matter	cannot	be	determined	at	this	time, but	an	adverse	outcome	could	have	a	material	impact	on	the	financial	statements	of	Southern	Company	and	Alabama	Power. Georgia	Power	and	Mississippi	Power	have	joint	use	agreements	with	other	AT&T	affiliates.

## Mississippi	Power

## Kemper	County	Energy	Facility

In	2021,	2022,	and	2023,	Mississippi	Power	recorded	charges	to	income	associated	with	abandonment	and	related	closure	costs and	ongoing	period	costs,	net	of	salvage	proceeds,	for	the	mine	and	gasifier-related	assets	at	the	Kemper	County	energy facility.	These	charges,	including	related	tax	impacts,	totaled	$11	million	pre-tax	($8	million	after	tax)	in	2021,	$15 million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2022,	and	$17	million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2023.	The	pre-tax	charges are	included	in	other	operations	and	maintenance	expenses	on	the	statements	of	income.

Dismantlement	of	the	abandoned	gasifier-related	assets	and	site	restoration	activities	are	expected	to	be	completed	by	2026. Additional	pre-tax	period	costs	associated	with	dismantlement	and	site	restoration	activities,	including	related	costs	for compliance	and	safety,	ARO	accretion,	and	property	taxes,	net	of	salvage,	are	estimated	to	total	approximately	$15	million annually	through	2025.

Mississippi	Power	owns	the	lignite	mine	located	around	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility	site.	As	a	result	of	the	abandonment of	the	Kemper	IGCC,	final	mine	reclamation	began	in	2018	and	was	substantially	completed	in	2020,	with	monitoring	expected	to continue	through	2028.

As	the	mining	permit	holder,	Liberty	Fuels	Company,	LLC,	a	wholly-owned	subsidiary	of	The	North	American	Coal	Corporation, has	a	legal	obligation	to	perform	mine	reclamation	and	Mississippi	Power	has	a	contractual	obligation	to	fund	all	reclamation activities.	See	Note	6	for	additional	information.

See	"General	Litigation	Matters	Southern	Company	and	Mississippi	Power"	herein	for	information	regarding	litigation associated	with	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility.

## Plant	Daniel

In	conjunction	with	Southern	Company's	2019	sale	of	Gulf	Power,	NextEra	Energy	held	back	$75	million	of	the	purchase	price pending	Mississippi	Power	and	NextEra	Energy	negotiating	a	mutually	acceptable	revised	operating	agreement	for	Plant	Daniel. In	July	2022,	the	co-owners	executed	a	revised	operating	agreement	and	Southern	Company	subsequently	received	the	remaining $75	million	of	the	purchase	price.	The	dispatch	procedures	in	the	revised	operating	agreement	for	the	two	jointly-owned	coal units

questions.question: How much would Southern Company's Alabama Power and Georgia Power segments collectively be liable for in maximum annual NEIL policy assessments, and what financial impact could these assessments have on Southern Company's overall financial condition?
questions.answer: Alabama Power and Georgia Power would be liable for a combined maximum annual NEIL policy assessment of $143 million ($54 million for Alabama Power and $89 million for Georgia Power). These assessments could have a material effect on Southern Company's financial condition, as uninsured losses and other expenses, if not recovered from customers, would be borne by these segments and consequently impact Southern Company's consolidated financial results.

Since the 10-K explicitly states that uninsured losses could have a material effect on Southern Company’s financial condition, these assessments represent a significant contingent liability.

questions.question: How does the potential maximum annual assessment from NEIL policies for Georgia Power compare to the total annual dismantlement and site restoration costs for Mississippi Power's Kemper County facility, and what financial implications could this have for Southern Company's overall risk exposure?
questions.answer: The potential maximum annual assessment for Georgia Power under NEIL policies is $89 million, while the estimated annual dismantlement and site restoration costs for Mississippi Power's Kemper County facility are $15 million. Combined, this represents a total annual risk exposure of $104 million for Southern Company through its subsidiaries. This could significantly affect Southern Company's financial condition and results of operations if both events were to occur simultaneously, especially since uninsured losses would be borne directly by the company.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power has 210 employees.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power's maximum annual assessment under NEIL policies is $89 million.
Step 3: Extract from evidence_source_b - Mississippi Power's estimated annual dismantlement and site restoration costs for Kemper County are $15 million.
Step 4: Synthesize - Combine Georgia Power's NEIL assessment with Mississippi Power's Kemper County costs to calculate total annual risk exposure for Southern Company: $89M + $15M = $104M.
Step 5: Analyze implications - Southern Company could face material financial impact since these costs would be borne directly by the company if not recovered from customers.

questions.question: How much would Georgia Power be required to pay in maximum annual assessments under the NEIL policies, and how does this compare to the actuarial gain or loss impact on its pension obligations in 2023?
questions.answer: Georgia Power would be required to pay $89 million in maximum annual assessments under the NEIL policies. In 2023, Georgia Power experienced an actuarial gain of $125 million in its pension obligations. This means that while Georgia Power saw a reduction in pension liabilities due to the actuarial gain, it also faced a potential cash outflow of $89 million due to the NEIL policy assessments. These two figures represent contrasting financial pressures on Georgia Power—one reducing future pension costs and the other increasing potential insurance-related liabilities.
reasoning_steps: Step 1: Extract from evidence_source_b - Georgia Power's maximum annual assessment under NEIL policies is $89 million.
Step 2: Extract from evidence_source_a - Georgia Power recorded an actuarial gain of $125 million in its pension obligations in 2023.
Step 3: Synthesize - The $89 million NEIL assessment represents a potential liability, while the $125 million actuarial gain reduces pension obligations, creating offsetting financial impacts.

In	August	2019,	the	FCC	stayed	the	case	in	favor	of	arbitration,	which	AT&T	has	not pursued.	The	joint	use	agreement	remains	in	effect.	The	ultimate	outcome	of	this	matter	cannot	be	determined	at	this	time, but	an	adverse	outcome	could	have	a	material	impact	on	the	financial	statements	of	Southern	Company	and	Alabama	Power. Georgia	Power	and	Mississippi	Power	have	joint	use	agreements	with	other	AT&T	affiliates.

## Mississippi	Power

## Kemper	County	Energy	Facility

In	2021,	2022,	and	2023,	Mississippi	Power	recorded	charges	to	income	associated	with	abandonment	and	related	closure	costs and	ongoing	period	costs,	net	of	salvage	proceeds,	for	the	mine	and	gasifier-related	assets	at	the	Kemper	County	energy facility.	These	charges,	including	related	tax	impacts,	totaled	$11	million	pre-tax	($8	million	after	tax)	in	2021,	$15 million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2022,	and	$17	million	pre-tax	($12	million	after	tax)	in	2023.	The	pre-tax	charges are	included	in	other	operations	and	maintenance	expenses	on	the	statements	of	income.

Dismantlement	of	the	abandoned	gasifier-related	assets	and	site	restoration	activities	are	expected	to	be	completed	by	2026. Additional	pre-tax	period	costs	associated	with	dismantlement	and	site	restoration	activities,	including	related	costs	for compliance	and	safety,	ARO	accretion,	and	property	taxes,	net	of	salvage,	are	estimated	to	total	approximately	$15	million annually	through	2025.

Mississippi	Power	owns	the	lignite	mine	located	around	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility	site.	As	a	result	of	the	abandonment of	the	Kemper	IGCC,	final	mine	reclamation	began	in	2018	and	was	substantially	completed	in	2020,	with	monitoring	expected	to continue	through	2028.

As	the	mining	permit	holder,	Liberty	Fuels	Company,	LLC,	a	wholly-owned	subsidiary	of	The	North	American	Coal	Corporation, has	a	legal	obligation	to	perform	mine	reclamation	and	Mississippi	Power	has	a	contractual	obligation	to	fund	all	reclamation activities.	See	Note	6	for	additional	information.

See	"General	Litigation	Matters	Southern	Company	and	Mississippi	Power"	herein	for	information	regarding	litigation associated	with	the	Kemper	County	energy	facility.

## Plant	Daniel

In	conjunction	with	Southern	Company's	2019	sale	of	Gulf	Power,	NextEra	Energy	held	back	$75	million	of	the	purchase	price pending	Mississippi	Power	and	NextEra	Energy	negotiating	a	mutually	acceptable	revised	operating	agreement	for	Plant	Daniel. In	July	2022,	the	co-owners	executed	a	revised	operating	agreement	and	Southern	Company	subsequently	received	the	remaining $75	million	of	the	purchase	price.
